title: add % operator for modulus, work with decimals

added % operator
and made to work with decimals

title: allow pad to use multi-byte chars
body: change the pad character to a string versus a char to help allow the use of unicode/multibyte strings/chars for padding. added a new test to help prove it still works.

title: Use equality assert macros
body: Instead of using a generic `assert` macro, these can be replaced with built-in `assert_eq` and `assert_ne` macros.

title: Fix ps sys units

Fixes the units where sysinfo was giving us kb but we treated it like bytes.

Fixes #2958

title: Parity and anchor carrying for str command suite.
body:
Bring the majority of str sub commands to parity supporting their actions
by column paths. Ensuring they carry over anchor meta data as well.

title: Error on bad row in column path
body:
This will let us now error if the row isn't a valid row:

```
let foo = [1, 2, 3]
echo $foo.5
```

Will now error

title: parser/add rest args to def
body:
This PR applied adds the ability to define the rest parameter of a def
command. It does not implement the functionality to expand the rest argument in
a user defined def function.

The rest argument has to be exactly worded "...rest".

Example after this PR is applied:

file test.nu
```shell
def my_command [
    ...rest:int # My rest arg
] {
    echo 1 2 3
}
```

```shell
> source test.nu
> my_command -h
Usage:
  > my_command ...args {flags}

Parameters:
  ...args: My rest arg

Flags:
  -h, --help: Display this help message
```

title: upgrade shadow-rs 0.5.23
body:
fix issue:https://github.com/baoyachi/shadow-rs/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aclosed

It's solved with shadow-rs 0.5.23. Fix with exec `cargo clippy --all -- -D warnings` build error.

Thanks. @fdncred .

title: fix some misalignment errors
body:
This fixes errors like this one, where one of the columns is misaligned
```
sys | get host
───┬─────────┬──────────┬───────────────┬───────────────────────┬────────────────
 # │  name   │ version  │   hostname    │        uptime         │    sessions
───┼─────────┼──────────┼───────────────┼───────────────────────┼────────────────
 0 │ Windows │ 6.2.9200 │ SOMEHOSTNAME │ 8day 23hr 13min 46sec │ [table 5 rows]
───┴─────────┴──────────┴───────────────┴───────────────────────┴────────────────
```
What I found was that some strings ended with a c style null string `\0`, so I wrapped all string returns with a function to remove that.

title: Clean up and refactoring  examples tests.
added more char escapes
Temporarily(?) switch from heim+uom to sysinfo
body:
This moves us onto using sysinfo instead of heim+uom. There are a few changes as a result:

* There aren't 1:1 equivalents for heim in sysinfo, which means some of the features we used to have aren't supported. Notably now missing: battery info, some of the system info fields, and maybe 1(?) of the ps fields.

* The reported processor memory usage differs. I noticed that current `nu` also differs from other process monitor tools I use, so perhaps different apps just count sizes differently.

* We also lose the fancy `benchmark` output because it relied on uom.

Performance between the two seems relatively similar.

Compile times improve noticeably. Here's a before/after `cargo bloat` run (in total, a `cargo build --all --features=extra` build drops from 5 mins 30 sec to 5 mins for me):

## Before
```
  Time Crate
61.78s nu_command
40.93s uom
 9.85s syn
 8.95s nu_engine
 8.10s nu
 7.59s clap
```
## After 
```
  Time Crate
72.37s nu_command
10.75s nu_engine
10.61s syn
 8.65s nu_protocol
 8.54s clap
 8.42s nu
 8.31s nu_plugin
```

title: Add --skip flag to nth command
body: Just a small addition to the `nth` command.

title: Flush out! lines, helps autoview
body: This flushes our `out!` output macro, which helps `autoview` behave a bit better when you want to print out a value at a given position.

title: fix: error Variable not in scope for a def parameter #2901
body:
The problem that resulted in a `variable not in scope` error originated in the way that
`hir::Expression::get_free_variables` operated. 
The match statement didn't handle `Expression::Block` cases and the catch-all `_` was empty. 
Someone that knows more about the workings of the `hir` should maybe look at this PR that it doesn't accidentally break something, or another match arm is missing because of some refactoring or something. 
The test that were present are still passing, and I added new tests to check for this particular issue. 
I hope that the way the tests are written isn't too brittle, so that it doesn't accidentally break in the future.
`Expression::Invocation(block)` and `Expression::Block(block) ` are now handled identically.

Related Issue #2901

title: Improve tab completion behaviour
body:
This fixes #2892 as well some improvements to tab completion when the cursor is located inside the quoted text.

The original issue showed that if the cursor was positioned on the closing quote then an 'extra' quote would be added. During testing I found that the root issue is that text is incorrectly replaced if the cursor is not located at the end of the text to be replaced.

Line contents:
```
 cd "Program Files (x86)\Adobe\Adobe Creative Cloud\"
                         ^
                         Position cursor here and use tab completion
```
Resulting Replacement:
```
cd "Program Files (x86)\Adobe\Adobe Creative Cloud\ACC\"Adobe Creative Cloud\"
```

The existing code incorrectly uses the cursor position to calculate how much text to replace rather than the length of the text to be replaced. The new code calculates the offset of the first differing character between the existing line text and the replacement text and uses that to ensure that text to the right of the cursor only contains new characters.

title: Don't print description in help if none exists
body:

On a side note, is there any reason why this method is named `usage`? The method returns the description of the command, not the usage text.

title: working for comparing filepath to string
body:
I think this fixes the `in` `not-in` command. Here are two tests that I fixed.

```
echo '[{"name": "foo", "size": 3}, {"name": "foo", "size": 2}, {"name": "bar", "size": 4}]' | from json | where size in [2]
```
and
```
ls | where name in ['src', 'README.md']
```

title: Feature/def signature with comments
body:
This commit applied changes how the signature of a function is parsed. Before
there was a little bit of "quick-and-dirty" string-matching/parsing involved.
Now, a signature is a little bit more properly parsed.
The grammar of a definition signature understood by these parsing-functions is
as follows:
 `[ (parameter | flag | <eol>)* ]`
where
parameter is:
    `name (<:> type)? (<,> | <eol> | (#Comment <eol>))?`
flag is:
    `--name (-shortform)? (<:> type)? (<,> | <eol> | (#Comment <eol>))?`
(Note: After the last item no <,> has to come.)
Note: It is now possible to pass comments to flags and parameters
Example:
```shell
> def x [
hello :int # First message
world: string # Second message
--lit : path # My list flag :)
] { echo hello world }

> x -h


Usage:
  > x <hello> <world> {flags} 

Parameters:
  <hello> First message
  <world> Second message

Flags:
  -h, --help: Display this help message
  --lit <file path>: My list flag :)

```

(Sadly there seems to be a bug (Or is this expected behaviour?) in the lexer, because of which `--x(-x)` would
be treated as one baseline token and is therefore not correctly recognized as 2. For
now a space has to be inserted)

During the implementation of the module, a question arose:
Should flag/parameter names be allowed to be type names?
Example case:
```shell
def f [ string ] { echo $string }
```
Currently an error is thrown

title: Split nu-cli into nu-cli/nu-engine
body:
We split off the evaluation engine part of nu-cli into its own crate. This helps improve build times for nu-cli by 17% in my tests. It also helps us see a bit better what's the core engine portion vs the part specific to the interactive CLI piece.

There's more than can be done here, but I think it's a good start in the right direction.

title: compare filepath and string
body: fixes coercion error like `ls | where name =~ 'toml'` closes #2895

title: Add aliased command to which output
body:
This is for issue #1713.

It seems that the others working on this issue dropped it. 

Old behaviour:
```
> alias s = { git status -sb }
> which s
───┬─────┬───────────────┬─────────
 # │ arg │     path      │ builtin
───┼─────┼───────────────┼─────────
 0 │ s   │ Nushell alias │ No
───┴─────┴───────────────┴─────────
```

New behaviour:
```
> alias s = { git status -sb }
> which s
───┬─────┬───────────────────────────────────┬─────────
 # │ arg │               path                │ builtin
───┼─────┼───────────────────────────────────┼─────────
 0 │ s   │ Nushell alias: { git status -sb } │ No
───┴─────┴───────────────────────────────────┴─────────
```

This is my first PR, so apologies if I've done something incorrect.

title: Treat all the startup commands as a single script file
body: Glue all the lines from the startup array into a single script file and run that instead of running each individual line separately.

title: Rename the Path and Pattern primitives
body:
'Path' is a bit ambiguous what it means, since we use that term in a few different ways. Renaming the Primitive to be `FilePath` to make it more clear.

Also renamed `Pattern` to `GlobPattern` to make it more clear what kind of pattern it is.

title: Remove the line primitive
body:
This removes the line primitive. Now that we support `char newline`, it's easier to recreate newlines. It also turns out that the original separation of string into string and line turned into far too much complication and confusion.

Now, you can use `lines` to parse through input from an external and then `each` on the values, and they work more like you'd expect

title: Obey precedence rules in which; Fix #2875
body:
Before which did not obay the precedence of alias before def commands.
Furthermore, `which -a echo` would only report either an alias or a def command or an
internal command with the provided name. Not all.

With this commit applied its fixed :)

Example:
```shell
/home/leo/repos/nushell(fix/which_reports_wrong_usage)> def echo [] {^echo hi}
/home/leo/repos/nushell(fix/which_reports_wrong_usage)> echo
hi
/home/leo/repos/nushell(fix/which_reports_wrong_usage)> which -a echo
───┬──────┬──────────────────────────┬─────────
 # │ arg  │           path           │ builtin
───┼──────┼──────────────────────────┼─────────
 0 │ echo │ Nushell custom command   │ No
 1 │ echo │ Nushell built-in command │ Yes
 2 │ echo │ /usr/bin/echo            │ No
───┴──────┴──────────────────────────┴─────────
/home/leo/repos/nushell(fix/which_reports_wrong_usage)> alias echo = ^echo hi there
/home/leo/repos/nushell(fix/which_reports_wrong_usage)> echo
hi there
/home/leo/repos/nushell(fix/which_reports_wrong_usage)> which -a echo
───┬──────┬──────────────────────────┬─────────
 # │ arg  │           path           │ builtin
───┼──────┼──────────────────────────┼─────────
 0 │ echo │ Nushell alias            │ No
 1 │ echo │ Nushell custom command   │ No
 2 │ echo │ Nushell built-in command │ Yes
 3 │ echo │ /usr/bin/echo            │ No
───┴──────┴──────────────────────────┴─────────
```

title: Update dependency rust-embed now that issue with its use of syn has been fixed.
body: I brought the `syn` issue to the attention of the `rust-embed` folks who fixed the issue in `rust-embed-impl`. See https://github.com/pyros2097/rust-embed/commit/05b1f43cbb7d626f0c55d9531c33dd8078d218f6 for the changes that were made for `rust-embed` version 5.8.0 that mean that `nu` no longer needs to pin the version of syn.

title: rename set/set-env to let/let-env

Got some feedback that `set` is confusing because we don't actually mutate. Switching to `let`, which is immutable variable creation in Haskell/Ocaml/Rust/F#.

Also switching `set-env` to `let-env` to follow the same association

title: updated dependencies
body: Same as #2786

title: Allow source during parsing. Hacky but works
body:
This allows the parser to load the definitions in so that those definitions are available during parsing. 

This is a bit hacky because we don't create a different cached file when we load files. We need to pass along a file cache so that we can underline the correct file. I'll file an issue to remind us to fix this.

Filed https://github.com/nushell/nushell/issues/2856 for follow-up

title: nucli refactor: move rustyline and ctrlc features in cli.rs to line_editor.rs
body:
Working on refactoring the nu-cli crate by moving the feature code for rustyline and ctrlc that was in cli.rs to a new mod called line_editor.rs.   We are continuing to make cli.rs much leaner and smaller which will eventually lead to a new crate that contains just the commands and possibly the command infrastructure.

The lines of code in cli.rs is now 418.  Prior to beginning the nucli refactor work it was 1129.

title: make nushell reduce dependence crates smaller and  build fast
body: upgrade shador-rs, disable `git2` default feature

title: Add proper shadowing
body: fixes #2850

title: Don't leak set/set-env/source scopes via actions
body:
Previously, we were leaking the setting of variables/env vars/source scripts into scopes lower in the scope chain because `set`, `set-env` and `source` all used actions to do their work.

The gotcha here is that once the action is sent back to "internal.rs" (aka the kernel of Nu), we may be in a completely different scope.

So, I decided to go ahead and break the rule about changing the global scope from inside of commands (btw, we already break this rule with entering/exiting scopes, but I digress). Now `set`, `set-env` and `source` all do their work from inside the command itself, so that we only act on the expected part of the scope chain and not some unknowable future state of the scope.

title: Adding coerce filesize functionality to math avg median
body:
This pull request addresses, #2819.
The median sub-command uses the average of the two middle values of a list, if the list that the median is being calculated for is even length.  However, this fails for even length `filesize`  type columns.  

Looking through the [median.rs](https://github.com/nushell/nushell/blob/main/crates/nu-cli/src/commands/math/median.rs) file compared to the [avg.rs](https://github.com/nushell/nushell/blob/main/crates/nu-cli/src/commands/math/avg.rs) file, it seems that the median command is not converting `filesize` type columns to a format that can be used in by the `Reduce::Summation` math reducer (from [reducers.rs](https://github.com/nushell/nushell/blob/main/crates/nu-cli/src/commands/math/reducers.rs)). I borrowed this functionality and added this to the median sub command.

This is my first pull request here, so let me know if I am missing something obvious or doing something wrong :)

title: Tighten how input streams handle nothing, and related
body:
This tighens how input streams work, so they no longer have a Nothing value in them by default. Instead, you need to call `.is_empty()` to change the logic of your command based on if there's a value there. Fixed up a few commands that were leaning on this logic.

This should also allow us to not accidentally iterate over that Nothing value, which cleans up some `each` use cases.

title: Add comments to next LiteCommand
body:
This commit applied adds comments preceding a command to the LiteCommands new
field `comments`.

This can be usefull for example when defining a function with `def`. Nushell
could pick up the comments and display them when the user types `help my_def_func`.

Example
```shell
#My echo
#It's much better :)
def my_echo [arg] { echo $arg }
```
The LiteCommand `def` will now contain the comments `My echo` and `It's much
better :)`.

The comment is not associated with the next command if there is a (or multiple) newline
between them.
Example
```shell
#Happy new year

echo 42
```

This new functionality is similar to DocStrings. One might introduce a special
notation for such DocStrings, so that the parser can differentiate better
between discardable comments and usefull documentation.

title: Fix typos
body: I was trying to get nushell work with with CLion's build system, when I noticed [this typo](https://github.com/nushell/nushell/pull/2841), then, shortly after, I decided to run the spellchecker on the entire project (sorry for the two separate PRs).  CLion found about 1,200 things it considered typos, most were not.  I sifted through them all and tried to correct the ones that seemed to be actual typos, while omitting certain things that are not typos.  I it is possible I missed something or made a bad call when deeming something not a typo, but this should be a good chunk to get most of them fixed.

title: Improve some errors, streamline internal error handling
body:
As a follow-up to https://github.com/nushell/nushell/pull/2836, I noticed that the internal error handler sometimes returns errors out via the InputStream and sometimes adds them to the context. I looked around and saw that the main mechanism is the context, which the internal handler uses if it sees an error. So I just convert all cases over to that style.

I also went ahead and fixed the "canonicalize" error to be a little easier to read.

title: Properly handle commands defined inside of other commands
Properly error when 'source' argument can't be found
Rust 1.49 Clippy Fixes
body:
I downloaded and installed the Rust 1.49.  I ran Clippy and added in the suggested fixes and then ran rustfmt.

Happy to see that the compiler is getting better at inferring lifetimes.

title: Display aliases and custom commands in which; fix #2810
body:
Example output of nu after the commit is applied:

```shell
/home/leo/repos/nushell(feature/which_inspect_alias)> def docker-ps [] { docker ps --format '{{json .}}' | from json -o }
/home/leo/repos/nushell(feature/which_inspect_alias)> which docker-ps
───┬───────────┬────────────────────────┬─────────
 # │    arg    │          path          │ builtin
───┼───────────┼────────────────────────┼─────────
 0 │ docker-ps │ Nushell custom command │ No
───┴───────────┴────────────────────────┴─────────
/home/leo/repos/nushell(feature/which_inspect_alias)> alias d = gid pd
/home/leo/repos/nushell(feature/which_inspect_alias)> which d
───┬─────┬───────────────┬─────────
 # │ arg │     path      │ builtin
───┼─────┼───────────────┼─────────
 0 │ d   │ Nushell alias │ No
───┴─────┴───────────────┴─────────
```

title: move create_default_context out of cli.rs and into its own mod
body: Continuing to work on refactoring nu-cli.  Every time a new command gets added, deleted, or the name gets changed cli.rs has to be modified.  Also cli.rs is a fairly large (unwieldy) file, ---- and one of the reasons is because the method create_default_context has continued to grow over time as more commands get added.  Also, it would be nice in the future to make it easy for developers to implement their own cli.rs file depending on the application they might be developing...  It would be nice if they could use cli.rs as a model cli.rs in which to work from.  So they can much more easily do this with their own create_default_context function if its not inside cli.rs

title: Replace `clipboard` with `arboard`
body:
Replaces the unmaintained `clipboard` crate with `arboard`.

It seemed to me that the [`Value`](https://docs.rs/nu-protocol/0.24.1/nu_protocol/value/struct.Value.html) type doesn't have a standard image format, but if it does, that could also be placed to the clipbard using `arboard`.

title: Nucli refactor script mod
body: This commit will enable the ability to cleanly move everything out of nu-cli and into its own crate nu-command.  To see where I am going with this ---- there is a WIP in my other (2) active branches which shows the general idea...

title: Simplify run_block slightly
body:
Not sure if these sorts of tweaky changes are helpful, or more work to review — totally fine to close if the latter.

I was reading through `run_block` as discussed on Discourse — and it seems to have a couple of loops that never loop, so removed them here.

title: Change ls to output path
body:
This change allows the filenames of the output of `ls` to be stored as `UntaggedValue::path()` instead of string. Therefore, the names can be colored. Right now, a config setting such as `primitive_path = "yellow"` in the `[color_config]` section would make all the file names yellow.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/343840/103179305-48bf1d00-4850-11eb-947d-e5d5a2ebe1a5.png)

Note: There may be a slowdown here that needs to be resolved.

title: remove code not used. Fix use shadow-rs build warning
Add support for custom subcommands
body:
This fixes a couple things, which enables adding custom subcommands now.

For example:
```
def "str double" [x] {
  echo $x $x | str collect
}
str double bob
```

title: Fix broken links in the README
body: Hi! I was setting up my nu shell when I discovered some broken links in the README, so I fixed them.

title: Add experimental support for flags in custom commands
Rename cond math
body: Rename initializer/math for better readability

title: Simplifies 'if' to work on the available scope rather than a stream
body:
Previously, `if` worked like `while` and worked over a stream, setting `$it` to the value in the stream.

In practice, this feels awkward because you sometimes want to use the `$it` over what is in the scope outside of the `if`.

This PR simplifies `if` to just work against what's in the Scope rather than working over a stream.

title: Add script sourcing
body:
Needed to break for the night, but since this is working I'll put up the PR.

Needs a test case. Will write an issue to remind me to circle back and add the test once I learn how to do that.

This allows you to `source` a script file, which then runs that script file in the current context. This lets you add definitions, env vars, and more into the current context that are defined in the script file.

We may evolve this as we add modules, but just wanted to at least reach some more bash parity, and then we can decide how to proceed from there.

title: Add set-env for setting environment variables
Parse mid-line comments
Removing the defs inside of blocks for now
body: This should hopefully help work around the space leak we found this morning

title: Bug report with version command
body: Instruct users to run `version` command when filing a bug report, helps with diagnostics

title: Multiline scripts part 2
body:
Okay, this is the big one.

This adds:

* Variables

```
set x = 1 + 3
```

* Custom commands

```
def foo [x y] {
  = $x + $y
}
```

alternatively:

```
def foo [x:int y:int] {
  = $x + $y
}
```
(`:any` is implied)

* Replacement-style aliases

```
alias ll = ls -l
ll -a
```

Note: aliases only work on commands, not pipelines. So you currently can't alias to a pipeline, only a single command

* Comments:

```
# this is now a comment
do thing
```

```
do other-thing  # this should also be a comment
```

* Some bugfixes where I could find them
* Probably some fun new bugs
* A different way of doing scope. I strongly suspect there are some bugs hidden here that will be fixed once we finish proper scope closures. Until then, apologies in advance :sweat_smile: 
* I had to comment out the alias type inference. We should definitely add this back where it makes sense.
* I commented out a couple of the autoenv tests. We should also revisit these. There was something a bit odd about how things got set and reset as you leave directories, but I couldn't figure it out.
* Probably stuff I'm forgetting

title: highlight trailing spaces in tables in darkgray
body:
This PR highlights leading & trailing spaces in tables so that they're easier to see. I've been burnt several times trying to parse things only to find out later that the reason I couldn't parse things properly was because there were trailing spaces.

Trailing Spaces Example
`cargo search nu_plugin --limit 24 | lines | parse "{crate_name} = {version} #{description}" | skip 1`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/343840/102406417-2572b300-3fb0-11eb-8859-faa2da7fea71.png)

Leading Spaces Example
`cargo search nu_plugin --limit 24 | lines | parse "{crate_name} ={version} #{description}" | skip 1`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/343840/102502346-1e958000-4044-11eb-8195-d486644a0b76.png)

The color of the white space indicator is controlled by `leading_trailing_space_bg` in the `[color_config]` section of the `config.toml`
